Yes, there are several organizations and individuals working to support Tibetan Buddhists in China. Some of these include:

1. International Campaign for Tibet (ICT): The ICT is a non-profit organization that works to promote human rights and democracy for Tibetans in China. They work with policymakers, Tibet advocates, and grassroots supporters to raise awareness of the human rights situation in Tibet.

2. Human Rights Watch (HRW): HRW is an international non-governmental organization that investigates human rights abuses worldwide. They work to document and report on abuses against Tibetan Buddhists in China.

3. Free Tibet: Free Tibet is a non-profit organization that works to promote the human rights of Tibetans in China. They work to raise awareness of the situation in Tibet and to support Tibetan Buddhists in their struggle for religious freedom and cultural preservation.

4. Dalai Lama: The Dalai Lama is the spiritual leader of the Tibetan people and has been a prominent advocate for the rights of Tibetan Buddhists. He has spoken out against the Chinese government's policies in Tibet and has worked to promote non-violence and dialogue between Tibet and China.

5. Anonymous: Anonymous is a decentralized international hacktivist group that has taken up the cause of Tibetan Buddhists in China. They have attacked Chinese government websites and exposed human rights abuses against Tibetans.

These organizations and individuals are just a few examples of those working to support Tibetan Buddhists in China. Their efforts have helped to raise awareness of the situation in Tibet and to promote religious freedom and human rights for Tibetan Buddhists.
